title: Help us ban plastic straws in the state of California! Please ... - Reddit
body: It was actually quite the fight since all the clubs are %99 rich elderly people who did NOT want to part with their precious plastic straws haha. Even the club I work at has gone back and forth between biodegradable and plastic due to the members throwing a fit. We just got back on the biodegradable train, thank goodness.
readable_content:
- amariek (2017-12-08): Help us ban plastic straws in the state of California! Please sign, share to any social media/friends and get the word out! I've already gotten a few restaurants in San Diego to opt out for biodegradable straws, the change is happening 💚

- lazyjz (2017-12-08): What restaurants in SD?

- vampyrotoothus (2017-12-08): Signed! I've wanted this for a while now.

- OctaviusPublius (2017-12-08): Is there a reason you are petitioning the federal EPA instead of the Californian government?

- napoleander (2017-12-08): While, I agree plastic shouldn’t be used at all, I do have a question. What would the impact of everyone using biodegradable be? They still have to be manufactured and the ones I’ve seen use a corn base and are compostable. But I’m not sure how much corn it takes to make the straws. Maybe y’all are using something completely different too. So basically I guess my question is what’s the side effect of millions of people using biodegradable straws during the manufacturing process?

- tayyylooor (2017-12-08): Yeah San Diego!
summary: The sentiment in the conversation about banning plastic straws is largely positive, as it includes efforts to promote biodegradable alternatives and support for the cause. There are also questions and concerns about the environmental impact of biodegradable straws, but overall, the tone is supportive of the initiative. Sentiment: 0.7
